description.narrative: Project improve legislative & strategic framework on corruption, supporting justice Sec,CoI process corruption offences and improv capacity & legal framework conduct commercial litigation, build Iraq’s ability to recover stolen assets , Gender equality,

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
Output 1: A) # of anti-corruption legislations drafted or reviewed and submitted for approval of the Council of Ministers or the Parliament including by the anti-corruption reform working group in Iraq with better compliance with international norms and best practice (disaggregated by type & sector).
B) # of oversight mechanism for the implementation of the anti-corruption strategies reflecting best international practice
C) # of regulation or Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) submitted for approval allowing implementation of witness and informant protection law
D) # of federal and regional Commission of Integrity (CoI) professionals trained on conducting impact assessment on anti- corruption legislation and conducting a corruption risk assessment to (disaggregated by type and sex)
E) Level of progress towards enhanced capacity of GoI to recover stolen assets (disaggregated by type)
F) i. # of coordinated responses of development partners to GoI on corruption issues and anticorruption reform ii. # of presentations on anticorruption programs, corruption issues and sectors jointly discussed by development partners
Output 2.1 : A) i. Level of progress in developing and implementing a trial monitoring programme A) ii. # of cases before the Central Anti-Corruption Court and other courts monitored by UNAMI.
B) # of federal and regional judges, prosecutors, and CoI investigators trained on corruption investigation, adjudication (disaggregated by designation of participants and sex).
C) # of federal and regional investigators mentored during investigation of corruption cases
D) i. # of Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) drafted or revised to address challenges stemming from investigations. (disaggregated by type of SOP). ii. # of justice professionals trained respectively on those SOPs
E) # of CoI officials with newly acquired skills on asset recovery
Output 2.2 : A) Level of progress to enhan

comment.narrative:
utput 1: A) a) No anti-corruption legislation drafted or revised under this project including by the proposed anti-corruption reform group fpr 2020 B)b) No oversight mechanism for anti-corruption strategies for 2020 C)c) no regulation or SOP is drafted for 2020 D) No professional of federal and regional CoI trained to undertake assessments on impact of anti-corruption legislation and corruption risk assessments for 2020 E) weak asset recovery capacity to be capture during the inception phase for 2020 F) i. no coordinated responses by development partners for 2020 ii. no common discussion of presentation on corruption problems and anticorruption measures for 2020
Output 2.1 :
A) i:No Trial monitoring programme on corruption cases exist in Iraq for 2020 A)II : No corruption cases monitored by UNAMI for 2020 B) No judges, prosecutors, and CoI investigators trained or mentored on corruption investigation, adjudication and asset recovery for 2020 C)no federal and regional investigator is mentored during investigation of corruption cases for 2020
D) i. No SOPs drafted to address challenges stemming from investigations and asset recovery for 2020 ii. No SOPs drafted to address challenges stemming from investigations and asset recovery for 2020
E) No training provided on asset recovery under this project. Baseline during inception will define needs for 2020
Output 2.2 : A) No review of this nature is undertaken to to-date for 2020
B) i. No training modules developed on revised integrity rule of the justice sector; no training of trainers conducted for 2020 ii. No training modules developed on revised integrity rule of the justice sector; no training of trainers conducted for 2020
C) i. SOPs not revised, no training modules developed on revised integrity rule of the justice sector; no training of trainers conducted ii. SOPs not revised, no training modules developed on revised integrity rule of the justic

Output 1: A) Draft or revise 3 anti-corruption legislations containing at least 6 compliance indicators with international norms (three legislations) B)Draft and submit for approval of one oversight mechanism for either the regional or federal anticorruption strategy integrating at least 2 international best practices C)Draft submit for approval at least one regulation or SOP to implement protection law at federal level D) Enhanced skills of 40 professionals of CoIs in impact assessment of legislation and corruption risk assessments (20 from federal CoI and 20 from regional CoI)
E) assessment of processes to identify gaps and weaknesses in the recovery of assets through bilateral agreements including assessment of the capacity of relevant GoI officials to initiate, conclude and use bilateral agreement F) i. At least 5 coordinated responses by development partners on corruption issues and anticorruption reform ii. At least 10 presentations jointly discussed by development partners
Output 2.1 :
A)i: Exposure and awareness raising on trial monitoring programmes and one trial monitoring programme on corruption cases is developed. A)II; N]A B) Minimum of 40 judges, prosecutors and CoI investigators are trained. (30 federal and 10 regional)
C) Minimum of 8 federal and 2 regional investigators mentored during investigation of corruption cases
D) N\A i. ii.
E) N\A
Output 2.2 : A) Conduct one survey of the Judge’s perceptions towards the code of conduct and one assessment of current judiciary integrity standards at federal level B) N|A i. ii.
C) N|A i. ii. iii.
D) i: 1 self-assessment conducted at federal level to determine the level of awareness and application of integrity rules by lawyers
ii. 1 self-assessment conducted at regional level to determine the level of awareness and application of integrity rules by lawyers
Output 3.1: A) 1 legislation drafted or revised(New York Convention)
B) N\A
Output 3.2: A) 2 initiatives implemented for federal Council of Representatives and regional Council of Representatives;
(Establish a joint working group to take action on integrity and corruption challenges composed of legislative and integrity committee, civil society, CoI and Board of Supreme Audit; information campaign on New York Convention.)
B) N\A
Output 4: A) 2 initiatives implemented for federal Council of Representatives and regional Council of Representatives;
(Establish a joint working group to take action on integrity and corruption challenges composed of legislative and integrity committee, civil society, CoI and Board of Supreme Audit; information campaign on New York Convention.)
Output 5 : A) N\A
B) N|A
C)1 initiative supported to enhance citizen’s access to information
(by-law or standard operating procedure)

Output 1: Improved Legislative and Strategic Framework for Anti-Corruption Reforms
-A ToR for the multi-disciplinary Anti-Corruption Reform Working Group was submitted to federal Commission of Integrity (CoI) for its consideration. Two meetings were held with the federal CoI to present & discuss the draft ToR for the Anti-Corruption Reform Working Group. -Federal and KRI legislative frameworks reviewed against standards set in UN Convention against Corruption, presented and discussed with both CoIs. -4 legislations reviewed: the draft federal access to information law, the draft KRI Shura Council law, the draft KRI judicial oversight authority law and the draft penal code (anti-corruption provisions only). -2 detailed presentations on international standards on access to information and the findings of the reviewed access to information law. Further, UNDP advocated with KRI CoI, Human Rights Commission, PMO and COMSEC for the enactment of the access to information instructions. -3 Trainings workshops were conducted in Erbil for federal and KRI CoI officials to enhance their: i) understanding of Iraq ranking in CPI; ii) skills on corruption risk assessment; iii) skills on anti-corruption legislation impact assessment. 67 participants (29 of them being women) from both CoIs took part in these workshops including some participants taking part in two consecutive workshops - ToR, establishment of and holding of 3 meetings of Anti-Corruption Coordination Forum - Draft concept of the High Level Anti-Corruption Forum
Output 2: The justice sector, lawyers and CoI are better equipped to process corruption offences due to (2.1.) improved technical skills relevant for corruption investigation, prosecution, adjudication and (2.2.) improved integrity rules of the justice sector
-Draft MOU with UNAMI Human Rights Office - 2 assessments of existing skills, training capacity and training needs in investigation and adjudication of corruption cases, one for federal and another for KRI - 1 assessment of the standards of conduct within federal and regional judiciaries and CoIs, - 1 assessment of the standards of conduct within federal and regional bar associations including existing skills, training capacity and training material and curriculum. - 1 survey of judges, prosecutors, investigators and lawyers about their awareness of judicial integrity designed
Output 3: Improved capacity and legal framework to conduct commercial litigation through (3.1.) better legal framework and capacity building for arbitration and (3.2.) further development of the commercial court
- 1 Assessment of federal and KRI legal frameworks on commercial arbitration against international standards notably the New York Convention to which Iraq is a party. - 1 Assessment of existing federal and KRI capacities, skills and needs for training - 1 Assessment of existing federal and KRI institutional arrangements and the need for institutional reforms
Output 4: Create a climate of support in Parliament for anti-corruption reforms
- 1 review of federal and KRI Parliamentary codes of conduct and legal awareness needs - 21 meetings in Erbil and in Baghdad, with the representatives of the legislative and integrity committees of both KRI and Federal Parliaments, civil society organizations, KRI and Federal CoIs and media to draft the ToR and launch the Anti-Corruption Forums between CSOs, Parliament and anti-corruption agencies.
Output 5: Increased transparency and public accountability
-3 key events around the International Anti-Corruption Day within the framework of KRI CoI public outreach and communication strategy including the production of integrity videos for awareness raising, a round-table, an exhibition, the launch and publication of KRI Anti-Corruption Strategy. -3 monthly Newsletters were released highlighting anti-corruption initiatives and events in Iraq. -1 Assessment of federal and KRI judiciaries and CoIs’s strategic communication and public outreach capacity and needs -1 Assessment of existing federal and KRI investigative reporting capacity and needs to enhance efforts in reporting on corruption cases.
